qas.question: Where is post-glacial rebound occuring most?

answers.text: Scandinavia and the Great Lakes region of North America.

qas.question: What has the ability to depress the crust of the Earth into the mantle?

answers.text: Large masses, such as ice sheets or glaciers

qas.question: With what speed does post-glacial rebound occur?
How much of a glacier's thickness is usually involved during crust depression into the mantle?

answers.text: a third of the ice sheet or glacier's thickness

plausible_answers.text: Scandinavia and the Great Lakes region of North America.

qas.question: Where has post-glacial rebound stopped occuring?
What totals a thirs of the glaciers length?
What happens quickly after the ice sheet melts?

plausible_answers.text: Large masses, such as ice sheets or glaciers,

qas.question: What pushes up the mantle of the Earth?

context: <a1_0><b7_0>Large masses, such as ice sheets or glaciers<a1_0/>,<b7_0/> can depress the crust of the Earth into the mantle. <b5_0>The depression<b5_0/> usually totals <a3_0>a third of the ice sheet or glacier's thickness<a3_0/>. After the ice sheet or glacier melts, the mantle begins to flow back to its original position, pushing the crust back up. This <b6_0>post-glacial rebound<b6_0/>, which proceeds <a2_0>very slowly<a2_0/> after the melting of the ice sheet or glacier, is currently occurring in measurable amounts in <a0_0><b4_0>Scandinavia and the Great Lakes region of North America.
